pain_points_original.title: Ensuring AI Data Sovereignty and Compliance
pain_points_original.description: DPC faces the critical challenge of adopting AI while adhering to "South Australian Information Privacy Principles." They specifically need measures ensuring "security and safeguarding of government data," particularly when tools integrate with "third-party offerings, particularly large language models."

pain_points_original.title: Seamless Integration with Legacy Systems
pain_points_original.description: The department needs to solve the technical complexity of fitting new AI tools into their current environment. They are seeking to "assess the maturity, scalability, and adaptability" of solutions for "integration into existing government systems" to ensure they function without disrupting operations.

pain_points_original.title: Establishing Viable Cost Models for AI
pain_points_original.description: DPC lacks clear financial data for this emerging technology context. They need to "obtain indicative costing models" to "inform future procurement planning and budget allocation," ensuring they can sustainably fund AI initiatives across business units for projects "beginning in 2026."

pain_points_original.title: Mitigating Implementation Risk via Proven Use
pain_points_original.description: Government adoption is risk-averse; DPC needs to validate solutions before rollout. They require "evidence of the tool's technical capability" and "lessons learned" from deployments in "similar sectors or government contexts" to avoid failure in public sector scenarios.

pain_points_original.title: Mapping the AI Capability Landscape
pain_points_original.description: DPC struggles to identify where AI can best "enhance efficiency" and "service delivery." They need to gather market intelligence to "compile a ‘catalogue of offerings’" and inform policy, rather than purchasing ad-hoc tools without a strategic understanding of "what AI tools... are in the market."
